title: Fertility among women aged between 15 and 49 years in South Africa

yaml.title: Fertility among women aged between 15 and 49 years in South Africa
yaml.author: Jerome Wendoh Milimu

markdown.markdown:
In DHS surveys, information is collected on current, past, and cumulative fertility. Drawing on the birth history information collected in the survey, the chapter begins with a description of current fertility. This is followed by a description of differentials in fertility by background characteristics. Then, attention is focused on trends in fertility, which permits an examination of changes in age-specific fertility rates by time periods going back 20 years from the time of the survey.

The chapter also presents information on the cumulative fertility of female respondents in terms of the mean number of children ever born and the mean number of surviving children to women classified by five-year age groups.

The chapter also presents information on birth intervals for births in the five years preceding the survey, age at first birth for five-year age groups of women and information on teenage pregnancy and motherhood by single year of age for youngest survey respondents, i.e., women age 15-19. These data are important because they indicate the beginning of a woman’s reproductive life.

The objective of the capstone project is to evaluate the uptake of HIV testing by social demographic factors among women aged between 15 and 49 years in South Africa. The data source for this analysis is the *2016 South Africa Demographic and Health Surveys(DHS)*. More info about the survey can be found [here](https://dhsprogram.com/data/Guide-to-DHS-Statistics/).

## Background characteristics

```{r}
# Load packages
  #if(!require(pacman)) install.packages("pacman")
pacman::p_load(
  janitor, # data analysis utilities
  here, # force rmds to use the project folder as working directory
  haven, # for reading in stata files
  tidyverse, # for everything
  gt # Create beautiful tables  
  )
```

```{r}
# Reading in the .dta file
ir_sa_raw <- 
  haven::read_dta(here("data/South Africa_IR71DT/ZAIR71FL.DTA"),
                  
                 # Provide a vector of column names
                  col_select = c(
                     v007, # Year of interview
                     v012, # Respondent's current age
                     v013, # Age in 5-year groups
                     v024, # Region
                     v025, # Type of place of residence
                     v045c, # Native language of respondent  
                     v106, # Highest educational level
                     v131, # Ethnicity
                     v190, # Wealth index combined  
                     v201, # Total children ever born
                     v212, # Age of respondent at 1st birth
                     v213, #Currently pregnant
                     v218, # Number of living children
                     v225, # Current pregnancy wanted
                     v501, # Current marital status
                     v525, # Age at first sex
                     v613, # Ideal number of children
                  ))
                  
                  
```

```{r}
# Look at a preview of the raw data frame
  # head(ir_sa_raw)
```

```{r}
# Renaming the variables
ir_sa_renamed <- 
  ir_sa_raw %>% 
  rename(yr_interview = v007,
         age = v012,
         age_groups = v013,
         region = v024,
         urban_rural = v025,
         native_language = v045c,  
         highest_educ = v106,
         ethnicity = v131,
         wealth_index = v190,  
         num_children_born = v201,
         age_first_birth = v212,
         pregnant_currently = v213,
         num_children_alive = v218,
         pregnant_currently_wanted = v225,
         marital_status = v501,
         age_first_sex = v525,
         num_children_ideal = v613)
```

```{r}
# Look at a preview of the renamed data frame
  # head(ir_sa_renamed)
```

```{r}
# Note the data class of each variable 
  # glimpse(ir_sa_renamed)
```

```{r}
# Convert from labelled data to regular factors 
ir_sa_clean <-    
  ir_sa_renamed %>%    
  haven::as_factor() 
```

```{r}
# Review data classes of the newly converted variables 
  # glimpse(ir_sa_clean)
```

### Bar chart

jhjh

```{r}
# Dodged bar chart showing the rlationship between education levels and whether particiapnts live in rural or urban areas 
ir_sa_clean %>%   
  mutate(highest_educ = factor(highest_educ, levels = c("no education",                                                                    "primary",                                                                         "secondary",                                                                       "higher"))) %>%   
  group_by(pregnant_currently, highest_educ, .drop = FALSE) %>%   
  summarise(number_of_individuals = n(), .groups = 'drop') %>%   
  ggplot() +   
  geom_col(aes(x = pregnant_currently,
               y = number_of_individuals,
               fill = highest_educ),
           position = "dodge")
```

### Box plot

hjhk

```{r}
# showing the distribution of life expectancy for each continent, 
ir_sa_clean <- 
  ir_sa_clean %>% 
    filter(age_first_sex != c("at first union",
                              "inconsistent",
                              "don't know"))  

ir_sa_clean$age_first_sex <- as.numeric(ir_sa_clean$age_first_sex)
    

ggplot(ir_sa_clean,         
       aes(x = age_first_sex,             
           y = reorder(ethnicity, age_first_sex),             
           fill = ethnicity,
           color = ethnicity)) + 
  geom_boxplot() + 
  geom_jitter(width = 0.25,             
              alpha = 0.5) +
  stat_summary(fun = "mean",
               geom = "point",
               size = 3,
               shape = 23,
               fill = "white")
```

## Area plot

```{r}

ir_sa_clean <- 
  ir_sa_clean %>% 
    filter(num_children_ideal != c("non-numeric response",
                              "don't know"))  

ir_sa_clean$num_children_ideal <- as.numeric(ir_sa_clean$num_children_ideal)


ir_sa_clean_2 <- 
  ir_sa_clean %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c("num_children_born", 
                        "num_children_alive", 
                        "num_children_ideal"),
               
    names_to = "children_born_alive_ideal",
    values_to = "children_count")

# Area plot of treated cases over time
ir_sa_clean_2 %>%
  ggplot(
      aes(x = age, # Map 'period' to the x-axis
          y = children_count, # Map 'value' to the y-axis
           fill = children_born_alive_ideal # Map 'variable_name' to the fill aesthetic
              )) +
        # geom_area() creates an area plot
      geom_area() +
       facet_grid(cols = vars(children_born_alive_ideal))
```

kjkhkh

```{r}
ir_sa_clean_2 %>%
  ggplot(
      aes(x = age, # Map 'period' to the x-axis
          y = children_count, # Map 'value' to the y-axis
           fill = children_born_alive_ideal # Map 'variable_name' to the fill aesthetic
              )) +
        # geom_area() creates an area plot
      geom_area() 
```

## Stacked bar chart

```{r}
# Stacked bar plots of y = counts by x = cut,
ggplot(ir_sa_clean, 
       aes(x = wealth_index, 
           y = num_children_born)) +
  geom_col(aes(color = urban_rural, 
               fill = urban_rural), 
           position = position_stack()) 

# Stacked bar plots of y = counts by x = cut,
ggplot(ir_sa_clean, 
       aes(x = wealth_index, 
           y = num_children_born)) +
  geom_col(aes(color = urban_rural, 
               fill = urban_rural), 
           position = "fill") 
```

### Table

```{r}

ir_sa_clean <- 
  ir_sa_clean %>% 
    filter(age_first_birth >= 9)

ir_sa_clean_3 <- 
  ir_sa_clean %>% 
    summarise(Min = min(age_first_birth, na.rm = TRUE),
              Mean = mean(age_first_birth, na.rm = TRUE),
              Max = max(age_first_birth, na.rm = TRUE), 
              .by = "region"
)
```

```{r}
ir_sa_clean_3 %>% 
  gt() %>% 
  tab_spanner(
    label = "Age of First Birth by Province",
    columns = -region
  ) %>% 
  cols_label_with(fn = str_to_title) %>% 
  fmt_number(decimals = 2) %>% 
  cols_align("left", columns = region)
```

```{r}
gauteng_ir_sa_clean <- 
  ir_sa_clean %>% 
    filter(region == "gauteng")

gauteng_ir_sa_clean %>% 
  ggplot(
    aes(x = age_first_birth,
        y = region)) +
  
  geom_violin(fill = "dodgerblue4") +
  theme_void()

```

```{r}
plot_violin_region <- function(my_region) {
 gauteng_ir_sa_clean <- 
  ir_sa_clean %>% 
    filter(region == my_region)

gauteng_ir_sa_clean %>% 
  ggplot(
    aes(x = age_first_birth,
        y = region)) +
  
  geom_violin(fill = "dodgerblue4") +
  theme_void() +
  coord_cartesian(
    xlim = range(ir_sa_clean$age_first_birth, na.rm = TRUE)
  )
}


plot_violin_region("limpopo")
```

```{r}
ir_sa_clean_3 %>%
  mutate(Distribution = region) %>% 
  gt() %>% 
  tab_spanner(
    label = "Age of First Birth by Province",
    columns = -region
  ) %>% 
  cols_label_with(fn = str_to_title) %>% 
  fmt_number(decimals = 2) %>% 
  cols_align("left", columns = region) %>% 
    text_transform(
      locations = cells_body(columns = "Distribution"),
      fn = function(column) {
        map(column, plot_violin_region) %>% 
          ggplot_image(height = px(50), aspect_ratio = 3)
      }
    )
```
markdown.srcMarkdownNoYaml:
# Introduction

In DHS surveys, information is collected on current, past, and cumulative fertility. Drawing on the birth history information collected in the survey, the chapter begins with a description of current fertility. This is followed by a description of differentials in fertility by background characteristics. Then, attention is focused on trends in fertility, which permits an examination of changes in age-specific fertility rates by time periods going back 20 years from the time of the survey.

The chapter also presents information on the cumulative fertility of female respondents in terms of the mean number of children ever born and the mean number of surviving children to women classified by five-year age groups.

The chapter also presents information on birth intervals for births in the five years preceding the survey, age at first birth for five-year age groups of women and information on teenage pregnancy and motherhood by single year of age for youngest survey respondents, i.e., women age 15-19. These data are important because they indicate the beginning of a woman’s reproductive life.

The objective of the capstone project is to evaluate the uptake of HIV testing by social demographic factors among women aged between 15 and 49 years in South Africa. The data source for this analysis is the *2016 South Africa Demographic and Health Surveys(DHS)*. More info about the survey can be found [here](https://dhsprogram.com/data/Guide-to-DHS-Statistics/).

## Background characteristics

```{r}
# Load packages
  #if(!require(pacman)) install.packages("pacman")

  janitor, # data analysis utilities
```

```{r}
                     v218, # Number of living children
```
